content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-263-10-B |Item_parent=Vascular nephropathy |Item_parent_short=Vascular nephropathy |Rank=B |Title=Know how to diagnose renal infarction, benign nephroangiosclerosis and cholesterol crystal embolism disease. |Description=None |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors=Jean-Jacques Boffa |Order=10}} '''Renal infarction:''' *The picture is brutal and may associate : **back pain mimicking renal colic" or abdominal pain; **macroscopic haematuria; **hypertensive flare-up; **anuria if the occlusion is bilateral or in a single kidney; **fever. *Biology: **elevation of LDH ; **variable elevation of creatinine; **inflammatory syndrome. *The diagnosis is confirmed by spiral CT scan, MRI angiography or arteriography. *This is an emergency because revascularisation (by intraluminal angioplasty or surgery) can only be performed in the first few hours following occlusion. The therapeutic alternatives are fibrinolytics and anticoagulants. '''[[Follow-up of a patient in chronic renal failure SD-290|Benign nephroangiosclerosis]] :'''' *This is often a diagnosis of exclusion, with no specific elements, and is based on a number of arguments: **background: cardiovascular history, cardiovascular risk factors, elderly subject, **Long-standing hypertension, often poorly controlled and with repercussions (left ventricular hypertrophy, hypertensive retinopathy); **slowly progressive chronic renal failure; **poor urinary syndrome: **no haematuria or leucocyturia **proteinuria absent or moderate; **kidneys of normal or reduced size depending on the degree of renal failure, symmetrical in size, with harmonious contours and no renal artery stenosis. '''Cholesterol embolism diseases:''' Diagnosis is based on the combination of an atheromatous background, a triggering factor and the clinical picture. Presentation of cholesterol crystal emboli {| class="wikitable" |Triggering factors |- On atheromatous terrain ++ : - Aortic surgery. - Arteriography (performed a few days to several weeks before the first signs appear). - Anticoagulant or thrombolytic treatment. |- |Clinical signs |- Often a few days or weeks after the triggering factor (latency period). - Acute renal failure. - Purple toes, livedo, distal gangrene. - Asthenia, myalgias. - Signs of mesenteric ischaemia. - Neurological signs: stroke, transient ischemic attack, confusional syndrome. - Vision problems. |- |Biological signs |- Inflammatory syndrome. - Eosinophilia, hypocomplementemia (these last 2 signs are inconstant). |} The diagnosis must be confirmed by one of the following 3 tests to identify the crystals: *fundus ; *skin biopsy of a livedo (risk of non-healing +++); *renal biopsy: this shows occlusion of small-calibre arterioles by cholesterol crystal emboli, with a significant inflammatory reaction in the vicinity. Further information is available at the following link: http://cuen.fr/manuel2/spip.php?rubrique21

question.title: What is the primary diagnostic approach for renal infarction, benign nephroangiosclerosis, and cholesterol crystal embolism disease?
question.description: The diagnosis of these conditions is based on a combination of clinical presentation, laboratory tests, and imaging studies.

option_a.title: Bilateral kidney ultrasound
option_a.description: An imaging study that uses high-frequency sound waves to create images of the kidneys

option_b.title: Spiral CT scan
option_b.description: A type of imaging study that uses X-rays and computer technology to create detailed images of the kidneys

option_c.title: Renal biopsy
option_c.description: A procedure that involves removing a small sample of kidney tissue for examination

option_d.title: Blood tests
option_d.description: Laboratory tests that measure various substances in the blood, such as creatinine and LDH
